questions.text: A female patient presents with complaints of pain over the anterolateral aspect of thigh after normal vaginal delivery. Which is the nerve injured in this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with symptoms of pain over the anterolateral aspect of the thigh is suggestive of meralgia paresthetica. It is due to compression neuropathy or neuroma of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve of the thigh. 

The lateral cutaneous nerve of the thigh arises from the posterior divisions of the ventral rami of L2 and L3, and it supplies the skin of the anterior and lateral surfaces of the thigh up to the knee.

It is prone to injury especially as it leaves the pelvis deep to the inguinal ligament just medial to the anterior superior iliac spine. The angulation of the nerve as it crosses the iliac crest makes it vulnerable to compression during hip extension which may increase angulation and tension on the nerve. This leads to impaired sensation, pain and paraesthesia on the anterolateral aspect of thigh, in the distal end of the cutaneous distribution of this nerve. The symptoms don't cross the midline, nor extend below knee or behind hamstrings laterally

questions.text: In the cardiac muscle, the inhibition of Na+K+ATPase results in __?
questions.solution:
The inhibition of Na+K+-ATPase results in depolarisation.

An energy (ATP)-dependent pump system (Na+/K+-ATPase), is located on the sarcolemma, which pumps Na+ out and K+ into the cell.The Na+/K+-ATPase pump is electrogenic because it extrudes three Na+ for every two K+ entering the cell. By pumping more positive charges out of the cell than into it, the pump creates a negative potential within the cell. This electrogenic potential may be up to −10 mV.

If this pump stops working (such as when ATP is lost under hypoxic conditions), or if the activity of the pump is inhibited by cardiac glycosides such as digoxin, Na+ accumulates within the cell and intracellular K+ falls,resulting in a less negative (more depolarized) resting membrane potential.

Inhibition of this pump, therefore, causes depolarization resulting from changes in Na+ and K+ concentration gradients and from the loss of an electrogenic component of the membrane potential.

Action potential of myocardium:

  • Phase 0: Depolarisation: Influx of Na+ into myocyte.
  • Phase 1: Early repolarization: Efflux of K+ from myocyte.
  • Phase 2: Plateau: Ca2+ enters myocardial cells via voltage regulated L-type Ca2+ channels.
  • Phase 3: Repolarisation: Efflux of K+.
  • Phase 4: Restoration of RMP: Restoration of Na+ and K+ by Na-K ATPase.

questions.text:
Match the following with their rate-limiting enzymes:
1- Heme synthesis a- HMG CoA reductase
2- Cholesterol synthesis b- Phosphofructokinase
3- Glycolysis c- ALA synthase
4- Niacin synthesis d- HMG CoA synthase
  e- Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1-c, 2-a, 3-b, 4-e.

Heme synthesis ALA synthase
Cholesterol synthesis HMG CoA reductase
Glycolysis Phosphofructokinase
Niacin syntheses Quinolinate phosphoribosyl transferase

Heme is synthesized in the normoblasts except matures erythrocytes. Heme synthesis is partly mitochondrial and partly cytoplasmic. It starts with the condensation of succinyl CoA and glycine by ALA synthase in the presence of pyridoxal phosphate to form delta-aminolevulinic acid (ALA). ALA synthase is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in mitochondria. 

All nucleated cells including the arterial wall can synthesize cholesterol and the liver, adrenal cortex, testis, ovaries, and intestines are the major sites of cholesterol synthesis. It occurs partly in the endoplasmic reticulum and cytoplasm. it starts with the condensation of two molecules of acetyl CoA to form acetoacetyl CoA synthase. 

The reduction of HMG CoA to mevalonate catalyzed by HMG CoA reductase is the rate-limiting step. it is the rate-limiting enzyme and is located in the endoplasmic reticulum. 

Statin group of drugs like lovastatin are competitive inhibitors of HMG CoA reductase and can be used in clinical practice to reduce cholesterol levels in the blood. 

Glycolysis converts glucose to pyruvate (aerobic condition) or lactate (anaerobic condition) with the production of a small quantity of energy. It takes place in all cells of the body. Phosphofructokinase is the rate-limiting enzyme that converts fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1-6-bisphosphate.

The rate-limiting enzyme of synthesis of niacin from tryptophan is quinolinate phosphoribosyltransferase. It converts niacin or nicotinic acid to nicotinate mononucelotide.

questions.text: A patient presents with ascites and edema. On examination, JVP was elevated. Gross examination finding of the tissue biopsy is shown. What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of ascites, and edema with elevated JVP points towards congestive hepatopathy. The image shows a nutmeg liver and chronic passive congestion of the liver. it usually occurs due to congestive heart failure.

Pathogenesis:

  • It is seen in patients with chronic cardiac lesions, especially those affecting the right heart (e.g., right-sided heart failure), which causes the blood to be damped back into the inferior vena cava and then into the hepatic veins.
  • This leads to increased pressure in the sublobular branches of the hepatic veins, which causes an engorgement of venous blood.

Gross appearance:

  • In chronic passive hepatic congestion due to heart failure, the centrilobular regions are grossly red-brown due to congestion and slightly depressed (because of cell death) and are accentuated against the surrounding zones of uncongested tan liver (nutmeg liver).
  • The appearance is called the nutmeg liver pattern due to its close resemblance with the cut surface of the nutmeg seed.

The image below liver with gross appearance as described above along with cut section of the nutmeg seed on top left corner.

Microscopic appearance:

Microscopic examination reveals centrilobular hemorrhage, hemosiderin-laden macrophages, and variable degrees of hepatocyte dropout and necrosis.

questions.text: A patient was infected by Bacillus anthracis. Under which of the following bioterrorism categories does this organism fall into:
questions.solution:
Bacillus anthracis which causes anthrax is categorized under category A bioterrorism agent.

Bioterrorism is the deliberate release of an agent by attackers that causes one or more of a variety of different diseases. The agents of bioterrorism are classified into 3 categories:

  • Category A bioterrorism agents are those which are easily transmitted from one person to the other and are associated with high mortality rates and thus have the potential to cause major public health impacts. Examples include Bacillus anthracis, Clostridium botulinum, and Yersinia pestis.
  • Category B bioterrorism agents are those which are moderately easy to disseminate and are associated with moderate morbidity and low mortality rates. Examples include Coxiella burnetti and Brucella.
  • Category C bioterrorism agents are those which are emerging pathogens that could be engineered for mass dissemination in the future due to ease of availability, high mortality and morbidity rates, and ease of production and dissemination. Examples include Nipah and Hanta viruses.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given an intravenous drug, and later, he developed abnormal movements. Which of the following can be used to treat him?
questions.solution:
The development of abnormal movements following an anti-emetic injection suggests that the antiemetic used in this case is probably metoclopramide. Benzhexol should be used in the management of this patient. 

Metoclopramide is a dopamine receptor antagonist used as a prokinetic and anti-emetic agent. It can produce extrapyramidal side effects and dystonia is seen acutely following intravenous injections. Anticholinergics like benzhexol (trihexyphenidyl) are used in the management of these side effects. Benzhexol is a centrally-acting anticholinergic agent. It acts by restoring the cholinergic balance in the striatal interneurons.

Acute dystonia is a movement disorder characterized by sudden, involuntary, and sustained muscle contractions, often leading to abnormal postures or repetitive movements.  It occurs after intravenous administration, while Parkinsonian-like symptoms develop weeks after therapy. It is managed with the discontinuation of metoclopramide and with anticholinergics or antihistaminics. Irreversible tardive dyskinesia can occur with chronic treatment.

Other adverse effects:

It can cause galactorrhea by its dopamine antagonism. Methemoglobinemia can occur if used in infants.

Other options:

Option A: Hyoscine (scopolamine) is a muscarinic receptor antagonist used in the management of motion sickness and vomiting.

Option B: Cyproheptadine is an H1 receptor antagonist used in the management of various allergy-related conditions like allergic rhinitis, anaphylaxis, urticaria, etc.

Option C: Levodopa is the precursor of dopamine and it is given in combination with carbidopa for the management of parkinsonism.

questions.text: A male was brought with the following injury in a gunshot incident. What is the possible range from which the weapon inflicted injury?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, based on the stellate-shaped wound seen, it seems to be a contact shot entry wound.

A contact shot entry wound on the skull typically has a stellate shape due to high-energy impact. 

  • Firearm wounds are fundamental of two main types: wounds of entry and wounds of exit. The wound of entry is the wound through which the bullet or pellets enter the body, and the wound of exit is the wound through which the bullet emerges out of the body.
  • To determine the range of firing, the following parameters are used:
    • The entry wound size and shape
    • Blast effect: Muzzle end imprint and edge eversion
    • Blackening, tattooing, singeing of hair, abrasion collar, and grease collar
    • Hair should be preserved to determine the range of firing which can be examined for carbonization/desiccation at close range, and also from lead deposition around the wound to assess the range of firing.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy with recurrent attacks of tonsillitis and speech difficulties was posted for a tonsillectomy procedure. Which of the following position is used in this surgery?
questions.solution:
Rose position is used in tonsillectomy surgery. 

In Rose's position, the patient is supine, with their head extended. A rubber ring is placed under the head to stabilize it and a pillow is placed under the shoulders to extend the head. Rose's position is also used in adenoidectomy and tracheostomy.

 

Indications of tonsillectomy are:

  • Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication
  • Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis
  • Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children
  • Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech
  • Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy
  • Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
  • As a part of the surgical management of sleep apnea syndrome, glossopharyngeal neuralgia, and Eagle's syndrome.

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

  • Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Overt or submucous cleft palate.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia.
  • At the time of the epidemic of polio.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

Other options:

Option A: The sniffing position involves flexion of the neck on the body and extension of the head on the neck which is done during tracheal intubation.

Option B: Semi fowler position is lying supine incline at an angle of 30 - 45 degrees. This position is used for patients who have cardiac or respiratory conditions, and for patients with a nasogastric tube. 

Option C: Reverse Trendelenburg position is lying flat with head 15 - 30 degrees higher than the feet. This position is used in ocular and ENT surgeries like minimally invasive cataract surgery and rhinoplasty.

questions.text: A hypertensive patient comes to the OPD with complaints of visual disturbances. On fundoscopy, multiple flame-shaped hemorrhages , cotton wool spots, and disc edema were found. What is the grade of hypertensive retinopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Cotton wool spots and flame shaped hemorrage with disc edema is seen in grade IV of hypertensive retinopathy. 

Grading of hypertensive retinopathy:

  • Grade 1: Mild generalized retinal arteriolar narrowing 
  • Grade 2: Focal arteriolar narrowing and arteriovenous nipping.
  • Grade 3: Grade 2 plus retinal hemorrhages (dot, blot, flame) or exudates (chronic retinal edema may result in the deposition of hard exudates around the fovea as a ‘macular star’ and cotton wool spots; may also be associated with banking of veins distal to arteriovenous crossings (Bonnet sign), tapering of veins on either side of the crossings (Gunn sign); copper-wire appearance; more prominent arteriovenous compression.
  • Grade 4: Severe grade 3 plus optic disc swelling (a marker of malignant hypertension) and silver-wiring of arterioles.

questions.text: In a 10-year-old school child, which of the following vaccines is given as a part of the immunization programme?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, a ten-year-old schoolchild will be administered the TT/Td vaccine according to the National Immunization Schedule.

The Tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d) as recommended for older children and adults. The MoHFW recommends the replacement of TT vaccine with Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

Scheduled to be administered at 10 and 16 years of age.

For pregnant women :

  • Td-1: early in pregnancy
  • Td-2: 4 weeks after Td-1
  • Td (Booster): if pregnancy occurs within 3 years of last pregnancy and 2 Td doses were received.

Other options:

Option A - According to the National Immunization Schedule, BCG should be given at birth or as early as possible up to 1 year of age. It provides protection against CNS and disseminated TB. A dose of 0.1 ml is administered intradermally in the left upper arm.

Option B - Measles/MR is given at 9 completed months (1st dose) and a second dose is given at 16-24 months. Measles can be given till 5 years of age. A dose of 0.5ml is administered subcutaneously in the right upper arm.

Option D - DPT vaccine is administered as a part of the pentavalent vaccine at the 6th, 10th and 14th weeks of life. DPT booster doses are administered at 16-24 months (first booster) and 5-6 years (second booster). It can be administered until 7 years of age (with booster doses). A dose of 0.5ml is administered in the anterolateral aspect of the mid-thigh. The 2nd booster dose can be administered in the upper arm.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of disability limitation?

choices.text: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy

questions.solution:
Prescribing spectacles for refractive error is an example of disability limitation which is a component of tertiary prevention. This mode of intervention is applicable when the patient presents late in the pathogenesis phase. 

The objective of this intervention is to prevent or halt the transition of the disease process from impairment to handicap.

Option B: Starting a patient on anti-tuberculous therapy is secondary prevention as it is a part of treatment.

Option C: Abstinence from smoking is a modification of the risk factor. Hence it is an example of primary prevention.

Option D: Early fixation of fractures will prevent disability. Hence, it is an example of secondary prevention.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs do not reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
The drug that does not reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure is furosemide.

The drugs which reduce mortality in patients with heart failure are :

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs)
  • Angiotensin receptor neprilysin inhibitor (ARNI)
  • Beta-blockers
  • Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists
    • Spironolactone
    • Eplerenone
  • Hydralazine + isosorbide dinitrate.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with amenorrhea, headache,  vomiting, loss of libido, and galactorrhea from 3 months. On examination, her vitals are within range but her eye examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following drug is preferred in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of prolactinoma of the pituitary. Among the given options, cabergoline is the preferred drug for this patient.

Prolactinoma: Prolactin-secreting lactotroph adenomas are the most frequent type of hyperfunctioning pituitary adenomas. The symptoms include

  • Headache and vomiting
  • Bitemporal hemianopia suggestive of a local mass effect
  • Increased intracranial pressure due to a pituitary tumor
  • In females- amenorrhea, galactorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility
  • In males- impotence, loss of libido, and gynecomastia

The diagnosis of prolactinoma is most likely to be associated with a prolactin level >200 μg/L.

Treatment is only required in symptomatic cases as microadenomas rarely progress to macroadenomas. The mainstay of treatment is medical management. Dopamine and dopamine agonists are used and they act as inhibitory signals to prolactin secretion in the pituitary. 

Cabergoline is a long-acting dopamine receptor agonist with high D2 receptor affinity and is the preferred drug for the treatment of hyperprolactinemia because of its greater efficacy and lower side effects. It effectively suppresses prolactin secretion for >14 days after a single oral dose. At higher doses, it is used in some patients with acromegaly, alone or along with somatostatin analogs.

Another drug used in prolactinoma is bromocriptine. It is shorter-acting when compared with cabergoline. The adverse effects of bromocriptine include hypotension and nausea.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presented with fever, cough, dyspnea, arthralgia, and a painful rash on the lower limbs suggestive of erythema nodosum. A chest X-ray was taken and the findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, together with the presence of erythema nodosum, suggests the diagnosis of sarcoidosis.

Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder of unknown etiology that is characterized by the presence of non-caseating granulomas.

In acute cases, patients may typically present with Lofgren’s syndrome, consisting of arthritis, erythema nodosum (as shown below), uveitis, bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, lethargy, and occasional fever. Patients may also present with insidious onset of cough, exertional breathlessness, and radiographic infiltrates.

 

Investigation findings in sarcoidosis are as follows:

  • Lymphopenia and deranged liver function tests 
  • Hypercalcemia (due to increased synthesis of calcitriol [1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D] by alveolar macrophages) and hypercalciuria (can lead to nephrocalcinosis)
  • Pulmonary function test - the most common abnormality is an isolated decrease in diffusion of carbon monoxide (DLCO). A restrictive pattern is seen in patients with more advanced pulmonary disease. Approximately 15-20% of patients have an obstructive pattern
  • Bronchoscopy shows a typical 'cobblestone' appearance of the mucosa. Bronchial and transbronchial biopsies reveal non-caseating granulomas. An increased CD4:CD8 T-cell ratio may be seen in bronchoalveolar lavage
  • Chest X-ray is useful for staging sarcoidosis
  • HRCT shows reticulonodular opacities that follow a perilymphatic distribution centered on broncho-vascular bundles and the subpleural areas

The presence of erythema nodosum with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest X-ray is sufficient to make the diagnosis of sarcoidosis. A tissue biopsy is not required in this case. A typical presentation with classical HRCT features may also indicate the diagnosis. In all other cases, the diagnosis should be confirmed by histological examination of the involved organ.

A chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy in sarcoidosis is shown below,

Management of sarcoidosis is as follows:

  • Asymptomatic patients- monitored for disease progression
  • Localized/ limited cutaneous and ocular lesions- treated using topical steroids
  • Multisystem involvement:
    • Systemic steroids
    • Other drugs like hydroxychloroquine, methotrexate, and infliximab are considered when the steroids are ineffective or not tolerated

Other options:

Option A: The chest radiograph of a patient with lobar pneumonia right middle lobe is given below. Note the prominent wedge-shaped area of airspace consolidation in the right lung, which is characteristic of acute bacterial lobar pneumonia.

 

Option C: The chest radiograph given below shows extensive bilateral reticulonodular infiltrates seen in miliary tuberculosis.

 

Option D: The chest radiograph given below shows cannon-ball lesions of metastatic lung cancer.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man with a history of diarrhea and abdominal pain since 6 months comes to the clinic with worsening abdominal pain. Endoscopy is performed. All of the following endoscopic findings are associated with the condition shown in the image below except:
questions.solution:
The endoscopic image showing cobblestone appearance along with the clinical scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease. Fine granular mucosa is seen in ulcerative colitis.

Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include:

  • Aphthous ulcers- Small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers- Linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Cobblestone appearance- Deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa
  • Strictures 
  • Fistulas.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding after accidentally spilling hydrofluoric acid over his hand. What is the preferred initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of hydrofluoric acid skin burns is with the application of calcium carbonate gel.

Immediate first aid to help prevent severe injuries from a chemical burn include:

  • Carefully remove the chemical and any contaminated clothing
    • Remove the chemical and contaminated clothing from contact with the skin and eyes
    • Do not wipe the skin as this may spread contamination
    • If the chemical is dry, brush it off the skin
    • Use gloves or other protective materials to cover hands and, if possible, carefully cut away clothing such as T-shirts, rather than pulling them off over the head
  • Rinse the affected area using as much clean water as possible
    • Rinse the affected area continuously with clean water as soon as possible
    • Try to make sure the water can run off the affected area without pooling on the skin
    • Only use water– do not rub or wipe the area

In very few cases initial management by lavage with water is not useful. Ex: Phosphorous used in some military devices and elemental sodium seen in laboratory explosions.

In hydrofluoric acid burns, initially, calcium gluconate gel is applied topically. Severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10 % gel. If the burn is with a concentration of greater than 50 %, then acute early excision is indicated due to the chance of hypocalcemia and arrhythmias. Split skin graft application to a hydrofluoric acid wound should be delayed and must not be done initially. 

Note - Although topical calcium gluconate is usually preferred, topical calcium carbonate gels may also be used for treating burns as they are also effective in providing calcium ions to complex the  free fluoride ions to prevent further toxicity.

questions.text: What nutrient deficiency is commonly associated with delayed wound healing following minor surgery?
questions.solution:
Delayed wound healing after minor surgery can be attributed to a deficiency in vitamin C.

Vitamin C, also known as ascorbic acid, plays a crucial role in collagen synthesis, a protein that is essential for wound healing and tissue repair. Collagen provides structural support to the skin, blood vessels, and other connective tissues. A deficiency in vitamin C can lead to impaired collagen formation, weakening of blood vessels, and delayed wound healing.

Factors influencing healing:

  • Infection: one of the most important causes of delay in healing; prolongs inflammation; increases the local tissue injury
  • Diabetes: most important systemic cause of abnormal wound healing
  • Nutritional status: protein deficiency and vitamin C deficiency inhibit collagen synthesis and retard healing.
  • Glucocorticoids (steroids): anti-inflammatory effects; results in weakness of the scar due to inhibition of TGF-β production and diminished fibrosis
  • Mechanical factors: such as increased local pressure or torsion; may cause wounds to pull apart or dehisce
  • Poor perfusion: due to arteriosclerosis, diabetes, or obstructed venous drainage; also impairs healing
  • Foreign bodies: such as fragments of steel, glass, or even bone; impede healing
  • Type and extent of tissue injury: affect subsequent repair;
  • Location of the injury and the character of the injured tissue: also important

Even though zinc also causes poor wound healing, Vitamin C is more commonly implicated.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for breast conservative surgery?

choices.text: Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis
Tumor more than the size of the breast

questions.solution:
Tumor size < 4cm, with N1 axillary metastasis is not a contraindication for breast conservative surgery.

Breast conservative therapy (BCT) involves resection of primary breast cancer with adequate normal breast tissue, adjuvant radiotherapy, and assessment of regional lymph nodes via a separate incision in the axilla. Removal of primary breast cancer is also called lumpectomy/ tylectomy/ partial mastectomy/ wide local excision.

Absolute contraindications of BCT:

  • Pregnancy
  • Persistently positive margin (2 microscopy shows positive margins)
  • Multicentric lumps
  • Diffuse microcalcification
  • Extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS)
  • Inflammatory breast cancer

Relative contraindications of BCT:

  • Active SLE (systemic lupus erythematosus), scleroderma  
  • Large lump-to-breast ratio (>5 cm size lump)
  • Known or suspected genetic predisposition to breast cancer (i.e., BRCA1, BRCA2), Li-Fraumeni syndrome (p53 mutation)
  • Multifocal disease
  • Prior radiation therapy to the chest wall or breast

questions.text: A patient is brought in to the casualty with maxillofacial trauma after an RTA. He is unconscious with a dropping SpO2. The ER doctor decides to intubate him. What is the preferred method of securing airway for this patient?
questions.solution:
Patients with severe maxillofacial trauma are very likely to experience severe airway compromise or obstruction. Hence to maintain airway competency, intubation is necessary and in the above case, the presence of facial trauma, tracheostomy is ideal.

Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. 

Functions: 

  1. Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction.
  2. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance
  3. Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood
  4. Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex.
  5. Allows positive pressure respiration
  6. Allows administration of anesthesia

Indications: 

  1. Respiratory obstruction due to 
    1. Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis, diphtheria)
    2. Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures
    3. Neoplasms
    4. Foreign bodies or edema
    5. Bilateral abductor paralysis
    6. Congenital anomalies
  2. Retained secretions
    1. Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles
    2. Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions
    3. Painful cough
  3. Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis

Other options:

Option A and B: Mask ventilation and LMA are not enough as the patient has severe airway compromise.

Option D:  Nasotracheal intubation is contraindicated in the presence of facial trauma because if there is an undiscovered fracture at the base of the skull, the tube could be forced through it and into the brain.

questions.text: A genital examination is being performed on a patient with perineal laceration post-vaginal delivery. The tear extends into the fascia and the musculature of the perineal body but the anal sphincter muscles remain intact.  Which of the following grades of perineal laceration does this correspond to?
questions.solution:
As the tear extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body and the anal sphincter muscles remain intact, this is a second-degree perineal tear.

The perineal tear is more common in primigravida and results from over-stretching or sudden stretching of the perineum during childbirth. Trauma to the perineum can also result in perineal tears.

Clinical features include the inability to hold the flatus and feces. Soreness over the peri-anal region can be seen due to constant irritation by stool. Palpation reveals the decreased/absence of a sphincteric grip depending on the degree of tear.

All recent tears should be repaired immediately. If there is a delay of 24 hours, the repair has to be withheld and the patient has to be started on antibiotics to prevent infection. Complete perineal tears that were not repaired in the first 24 hours should be operated on between 3-6 months after delivery. In 3 months of time, any local infection that might have been present would subside, and the general condition of the patient will also improve. However, if the perineal tear is untreated for more than 6 months, dense scar tissue forms making the surgery difficult.

Related Pearl: Degrees of perineal laceration

Degree
Description
First-degree
Injury to the skin and subcutaneous tissue of the perineum and vaginal epithelium only. The perineal muscles remain intact.
Second-degree
Extends into the fascia and musculature of the perineal body. The anal sphincter muscles remain intact.
Third-degree 
3a
<50% of EAS thickness is torn
3b
>50% of EAS thickness is torn
3c
Both EAS and IAS are torn
Fourth-degree
Involves the perineal structures, EAS, IAS and rectal mucosa.

questions.text: A girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth.USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles. Which of the following would be increased in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario history of irregular periods, acne, increased facial hair growth, and USG showing multiple ovarian follicles is suggestive of polycystic ovarian disease(PCOD). In PCOD, serum testosterone would be elevated.

Insulin induces LH to cause theca-cell hyperplasia and secrete androgens, testosterone, and epiandrostenedione which are converted to estrogen in the granulosa cells. Epi-androstenedione is converted in the peripheral fat to oestrone. This leads to rise in estrogen and inhibin levels. These in turn cause high LH surge. While the oestrone level increases, the oestradiol level remains normal which raises the Oestrone: Oestradiol ratio.

Endocrinological changes of PCOD:

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 - 70 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome 

Important clinical features of PCOS are Menstrual abnormalities (70%) - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea, obesity, hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism, acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance, and infertility.

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  • Oligo/ amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Hirsutism/ acne
  • Ultrasound findings-

Investigations

  • Enlarged ovaries with ovarian volume will be more than 10 mm3
  • 12 or more small follicles each 2-9 mm in size placed peripherally.

Hormonal studies

  • USG is diagnostic of PCOS - it shows enlarged ovaries with multiple follicles in the periphery. It also rules out other pathologies like ovarian tumors, endometrial hyperplasia.
  • Laparoscopy (therapeutic). It reveals bilateral enlarged ovarian cysts.

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

 

Management of PCOD is individualized. Weight reduction and lifestyle changes are the first-line therapy for PCOD. Oral contraceptive pills (OCP), preferably fourth-generation pills with 30 mcg E2 and 2-3 mg drospirenone are used to treat menstrual abnormalities. Hirsutism and acne are managed with OCP with cyproterone acetate and topical agents such as eflornithine, clindamycin lotion 1%, erythromycin gel 2%, and isotretinoin. 

Patients with PCOD are more prone to developing insulin resistance which can be controlled with metformin and acarbose. Patients presenting with infertility are treated by inducing ovulation using clomiphene as a first-line drug, along with dexamethasone and letrozole.

Surgical management includes laparoscopic ovarian drilling or puncture of not more than four cysts in each ovary.

Note:

PCOS in association with diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia and cardiovascular disease presenting in reproductive age group is known as "X syndrome".

questions.text: Identify the maneuver shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
The above image depicts Ritgen’s manoeuvre, a technique used during the second stage of labor to assist in the controlled delivery of the fetal head, reducing the risk of perineal tears and trauma.

Steps in Ritgen’s Maneuver:

  • The right hand is draped with a sterile towel.
  • The fingers of the right hand pressing posterior to the rectum exerts upward pressure to the chin and extends the head. The extension of the head prevents the head from slipping back in between the contractions.
  • The left hand placed over the occiput exerts a downward counterpressure to prevent the rapid extension of the head
  • The ritgen’s manoeuvre thus helps in the controlled delivery of the head of the fetus.

Other options:

Option B: Pinard’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of legs in case of frank breech presentation.

Option C: Lovset’s manoeuvre is used to facilitate the delivery of arms in breech presentation.

Option D: In Zavanelli maneuver is an obstetric procedure used as a last-resort technique during shoulder dystocia when other manoeuvres fail to deliver the baby vaginally. The fetal head is rotated to the pre-restitution position and pushed back into the pelvis to perform an emergency cesarean section.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about breast milk jaundice?

choices.text: It occurs due to the presence of glucuronidase
Phototherapy is not required in all cases
It occurs due to decreased milk intake

questions.solution:
Breast milk jaundice is not due to decreased milk intake. It is due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk.

Breast Milk jaundice is seen in about 2–4 % of exclusively breastfed babies. There is significant unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia after the 7th day and may last for 2–3 weeks. This may be caused by the breast milk that might contain β-glucuronidase, which deconjugates intestinal bilirubin and promotes its absorption and other inhibitors of glucuronyl transferase. Persistently high bilirubin levels may require changing from breast milk to infant formula for 24–48 h and/or treatment with phototherapy, without cessation of breastfeeding.

Breastfeeding jaundice (BFJ)

  • Early-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs in the 1st week after birth (usually appears after 24 - 72 hours of birth) 
  • Due to decreased milk intake with dehydration and/or reduced caloric intake. (Breastfeeding failure jaundice)
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and supplementation with formula feeds if needed.

Breast milk jaundice (BMJ)

  • Late-onset, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia of breastfed infants.
  • Occurs after the 7th day with maximal concentrations as high as 10–30 mg/dl reached during the 2nd-3rd week
  • Due to the presence of glucuronidase in breast milk (etiology not entirely clear).
  • Treatment: Continue breastfeeding and the bilirubin gradually decreases but may persist for 3-10 weeks at lower levels; phototherapy may be of benefit in some cases.

Related Pearl: Hyperbilirubinemia- Causes

questions.text: Which test is being performed to detect fixed flexion deformity at hip?
questions.solution:
Thomas test is used to detect fixed flexion deformity of the hip. 

Flexion deformity is seen in the initial stages of the disease. The patient keeps the hip in flexion as this is the position of ease and maximum joint capacity. Soft tissue contractures convert this into a fixed flexion deformity, making locomotion impossible.

In an effort to bring the limb on the ground and to make locomotion possible, the lumbar spine undergoes exaggerated lordosis and thus conceals the fixed flexion deformity. This is revealed by the Thomas test. The easy passage of the examiner's hand between the bed and the back of the patient is considered as a positive test as normally this is not possible.

Other options: 

  • Trendelenburg test is used to assess the weakness or paralysis of gluteus medius muscle. 
  • Telescopy test: To asses the stability of the hip joint. Positive telescopy test indicates hip dislocations or fracture neck of femur.
  • Ober's test is used in physical examination to identify the tightness of the iliotibial band.

questions.text: A patient stopped alcohol consumption for 3 days and presented with irritability, disorientation, paranoid delusions, agitation, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient who has not consumed alcohol for the past 3 days presenting with disorientation, paranoid delusions, visual hallucinations, and altered sensorium is suggestive of delirium tremens.

Delirium tremens is a medical emergency that occurs during alcohol withdrawal. It is an acute condition and usually develops within 72 hours after the last drink. It has symptoms of both delirium and alcohol withdrawal.

The clinical features of delirium tremens are as follows:

  • Altered sensorium with disorientation
  • Perceptual distortions, most frequently tactile or visual hallucinations
  • Autonomic hyperactivity with tachycardia, fever, anxiety, insomnia, hypertension, and sweating
  • Fluctuating levels of psychomotor activity, ranging from agitation to lethargy
  • Altered sleep-wake cycle

Other options:

Option B: Wernicke’s encephalopathy (alcoholic encephalopathy) is associated with thiamine deficiency. Alcohol abuse may lead to thiamine deficiency because of poor nutritional habits or malabsorption.

It is an acute neurological disorder characterized by

  • Global confusion
  • Ocular abnormalities like horizontal nystagmus, gaze palsy, anisocoria, and sluggish pupillary reflex
  • Ataxia - mainly affecting the gait
  • Vestibular dysfunction

It may resolve with thiamine therapy or progress to Korsakoff's syndrome.

Option C: Korsakoff’s psychosis can follow Wernicke’s encephalopathy due to thiamine deficiency. It is a chronic amnestic syndrome that is characterized by the following clinical symptoms in an intact and responsive patient:

  • Impaired mental syndrome, especially recent memory
  • Anterograde amnesia
  • Confabulation

Option D: Alcohol-induced psychosis is characterized by the development of auditory hallucinations or paranoid delusions in the context of heavy drinking or alcohol withdrawal. These patients have a clear sensorium, unlike the patients having delirium tremens.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy is rushed to the ER after having choked on a bone while eating. He is responsive but unable to speak. What is to be done next?
questions.solution:
In a choking child (more than 1 year old) or an adult, the first step to be done is to perform Heimlich maneuver, which involves delivering abdominal thrusts.

The rescuer should stand or kneel behind the patient and wrap his arms around the patient’s waist. A fist is made with one hand and using the other hand, the fist is driven into the patient’s abdomen with a rapid, forceful upward thrust so as to dislodge the foreign body. This is continued until the foreign body is expelled or if the patient becomes unresponsive.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

 

In a choking infant who is responsive, 5 back slaps between the shoulder blades and 5 downward thrusts on the chest are given in order to dislodge the foreign body.

If the patient becomes unresponsive, immediately start CPR.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with burning pain on passing urine. He reluctantly admits that he had unprotected sexual intercourse 3 days ago. The following examination findings are seen. Which of the following is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of this patient occurring 3 days after unprotected sex point to urethritis caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as its incubation period is 1-5 days.

The most common presentation of gonococcal infection in men is acute urethritis with dysuria and profuse purulent discharge. Pharyngeal and rectal infections can also occur depending on the type of sexual contact.

The primary site of infection in women is the cervix but the urethra, rectum, and pharynx may be involved. Symptoms include excessive vaginal discharge, dysuria, deep dyspareunia, postcoital and intermenstrual bleeding.

Other options:

Option A: The most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis (NGU) is Chlamydia, which has an incubation period of 1-3 weeks. It usually presents with dysuria alone, but mucopurulent discharge can occur.

Option B: Syphilis is primarily a sexually transmitted disease caused by Treponema palladium but vertical transmission is also possible. It commonly presents as a hard, painless genital ulcer with induration, followed by the development of rubbery enlargement of inguinal lymph nodes.

Option C: Herpes genitalis is an infection of the genital skin or mucosa with herpes simplex virus HSV 1 and HSV 2. It presents as painful genital ulcers and dysuria. It is usually preceded by a prodrome of general malaise.

questions.text: All are causes of high RAIU (radioactive iodine uptake) except:
questions.solution:
Subacute thyroiditis shows low uptake of radioactive iodine as it involves destruction and inflammation of the thyroid follicles, which also accounts for the thyrotoxic symptoms due to exocytosis of the hormone.

The other three are classical examples of high RAIU.

Radioactive Iodine Scan:

  • Nonpregnant, hyperthyroid patients with physical examination suggesting nodular thyroid disease, radioactive iodine should be the initial test to determine the aetiology of hyperthyroidism.
  • Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications to radionuclide imaging.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a high (or normal) radioiodine uptake indicates de-novo synthesis of the hormone.
  • Hyperthyroidism with a low (nearly absent) radioiodine uptake indicates either inflammation and destruction of thyroid tissue with release of preformed hormone into the circulation or an extrathyroidal source of thyroid hormone, such as in patients with factitious thyrotoxicosis and in patients with struma ovari.
